text: Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

text: Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones. Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial.

text: Patient: I’ll get these tests done and then we’ll come back to see you. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: And then the rest is done here? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: The treatment is here? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: The radium since it’s an injection is it IV injection or just a shot? Doctor: It is. No, they put a little IV in and then they kind of push it in over a minute and then you’re good for the month. Now, technically that’s liquid radiation so you’re kind of glowy. Patient: Ah. Okay. Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
